content.title: Thrombocytopenia Overview
content.summary: Thrombocytopenia is defined as a platelet count below 150 × 10⁹/L and is classified by mechanism: decreased production (marrow failure), increased destruction (immune, consumptive), sequestration (hypersplenism), or dilutional. Bleeding risk correlates with platelet count and function, with spontaneous bleeding typically occurring below 10-20 × 10⁹/L.
key_points: Mechanisms: decreased production, increased destruction, sequestration, dilution
First step: rule out pseudothrombocytopenia (EDTA-induced clumping)
Peripheral smear is essential: platelet size, schistocytes, blasts, inclusions
Transfusion threshold: <10 for prophylaxis, <50 for procedures, <100 for CNS/eye surgery
content.statement: Thrombocytopenia evaluation requires systematic classification by mechanism, confirmation on peripheral smear, and tailored management based on underlying cause with platelet transfusion reserved for significant bleeding or procedural needs.

explanation.intuition: Think of platelets like workers in a factory. Thrombocytopenia occurs when: (1) factory isn't producing workers (marrow failure), (2) workers are being destroyed on the job (immune/consumptive), (3) workers are stuck in the warehouse (splenic sequestration), or (4) workers are diluted out (massive transfusion).
explanation.key_insight: The peripheral smear is the most important initial test - it confirms true thrombocytopenia, provides clues to mechanism (large platelets = peripheral destruction, schistocytes = TMA, blasts = marrow failure), and guides further workup.
explanation.technical_details: EDTA-induced pseudothrombocytopenia occurs in 0.1% of samples from platelet agglutination by cold-reactive antiplatelet antibodies. Verify with citrate tube or smear. Immature platelet fraction (IPF) distinguishes production (low) from destruction (high) causes.

definitions_glossary.pseudothrombocytopenia: Falsely low platelet count from in vitro clumping (EDTA artifact)
definitions_glossary.megakaryocyte: Bone marrow cell that produces platelets; absent/decreased in marrow failure
definitions_glossary.platelet_destruction: Accelerated clearance of platelets; immune (ITP) or non-immune (TMA)
definitions_glossary.sequestration: Pooling of platelets in enlarged spleen; up to 90% of platelets may be sequestered
definitions_glossary.mean_platelet_volume: Average platelet size; increased MPV suggests peripheral destruction
definitions_glossary.immature_platelet_fraction: Percentage of young platelets; elevated in destruction, low in production failure
definitions_glossary.schistocyte: Fragmented RBC indicating microangiopathic hemolysis (TTP, HUS, DIC)
definitions_glossary.petechiae: Pinpoint hemorrhages in skin from platelet dysfunction/deficiency
definitions_glossary.mucocutaneous_bleeding: Bleeding from mucous membranes typical of platelet disorders
definitions_glossary.platelet_transfusion: Infusion of donor platelets; typical dose raises count by 30-50 × 10⁹/L
definitions_glossary.thrombopoietin: Liver-produced hormone stimulating megakaryopoiesis; TPO agonists used in ITP

decreased_production.features: Other cytopenias often present; low IPF; may need bone marrow biopsy

increased_destruction.features: Elevated IPF; large platelets on smear; schistocytes in TMA

sequestration.features: Mild-moderate thrombocytopenia (rarely <40); enlarged spleen on exam/imaging

dilutional.features: Clinical context obvious; resolves with replacement

bleeding_risk_by_count.above_100: No spontaneous bleeding; safe for most procedures
bleeding_risk_by_count.50_to_100: Minimal spontaneous bleeding; may bleed with surgery
bleeding_risk_by_count.20_to_50: Variable bleeding risk; prophylaxis for invasive procedures
bleeding_risk_by_count.below_10: High risk spontaneous bleeding; prophylactic transfusion indicated

initial_workup: Confirm on peripheral smear (rule out clumping)
Repeat CBC in citrate tube if clumping suspected
Review smear: platelet size, schistocytes, blasts, dysplasia
Complete history: medications, infections, bleeding symptoms

specialized: Bone marrow biopsy (if production defect suspected)

peripheral_smear_findings.large_platelets: Suggest peripheral destruction with compensatory marrow response

general_principles.bleeding_precautions: Soft toothbrush, avoid trauma, stool softeners

specific_therapies.ITP: Steroids, IVIG, TPO agonists, rituximab, splenectomy

definition.@value: A condition characterized by a platelet count below 150 × 10⁹/L, resulting from decreased production, increased destruction, sequestration, or dilution, with bleeding risk correlating to platelet count and function

scopeNote.@value: Overview concept covering classification, diagnosis, and management principles for all causes of thrombocytopenia

learning_objectives: Define thrombocytopenia and classify by mechanism
Interpret peripheral blood smear findings in thrombocytopenia
Recognize features distinguishing immune from consumptive thrombocytopenia
clinical_pearls: Always check smear first - platelet clumping = pseudothrombocytopenia (repeat in citrate tube)
Large platelets + elevated IPF = peripheral destruction (marrow responding)
Schistocytes + thrombocytopenia = MAHA - think TTP, HUS, DIC, HELLP
Isolated thrombocytopenia + otherwise healthy = think ITP
Avoid platelet transfusion in TTP - may worsen; plasma exchange is treatment
common_misconceptions: Platelets <50 always need transfusion - threshold depends on clinical context
Low platelets always cause bleeding - function matters as much as count
ITP patients have high bleeding risk - many tolerate very low counts without bleeding
